body: Hmm, what is `destroy_thread_sync_data`? Is this coming from C++?
@icing that's one of the functions we have refactored away since 8.13.0
@icing here is the link to function in [lib/asyn-thread.c](https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/1c3149881769e7bd79b072e48374e4c2b3678b2f/lib/asyn-thread.c#L159)
Thanks for helping an old man with his memory!ðŸ˜…

Hmm, this looks like the race we fixed later in the async refactoring. The problem is:

1. `Curl_resolver_cancel()` is called when a transfer is cancelled/done
2. calling `destroy_async_data()` which finds the resolving thread is not done yet
3. which sets `tsd->done` and cancels the thread (detaches and not joins)
4. and then calls `destroy_thread_sync_data().
5. the resolve thread in `getaddrinfo_thread()` sees the `tsd->done` and also calls `destroy_thread_sync_data()

If the easy handle is closed after 4 and before 5 is done, the thread will cleanup up freed memory.

Does that make sense?
@Wizermil any chance you can take 8.14.0-rc1 on a test spin to see if that perhaps already has this problem fixed?

@bagder I created a small program on macOS to reproduce the crash available in [this repo](https://github.com/Wizermil/curl-bug-17256)
Unfortunately it's not 100% reliable it also triggers other crashes but it's maybe because of bug in the app itself. I put it together quickly

@badger I tested the master branch and I didn't encountered any crashes (I also used thread sanitizer and address + undefined behavior sanitizer)
I also tested 8.14.0-rc1 and it's not crashing on macOS

repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
When cancelling a threaded resolve and the thread is still running, detach from it under the mutex lock.

Otherwise, the detach might happen after the thread finished and access already freed memory.

refs #17256
